GramExa.EXAMPLE: The salary is £18,600 a year, increasing to £23,000.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 薪水由每年18,600英镑增加到23,000英镑。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: the increasing difficulty of finding trained staff
European leaders watched events unfold with increasing alarm.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 眼看着事态一步步发展﹐欧洲领导人越来越恐慌。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: an increased incidence of childhood leukaemia
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 儿童白血病的发病率越来越高

Exponent.DEF: to become larger in number, amount, or degree
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Sales increased by 25%.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 销售额增加了25%。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The level of violence has increased.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 暴力升级。

Exponent.DEF: to increase. Go up is less formal than increase, and is the usual verb to use in everyday English.
Exponent.TRAN: 上涨﹐增加〔常用于日常英语中﹐不如 increase 正式〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The price of coffee has gone up.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 咖啡价格上涨了。

Exponent.DEF: to increase. Rise sounds a little formal and is often used when talking about the level of something increasing.
Exponent.TRAN: 提高﹐上升﹐增加〔稍正式﹐常用于指某事物水准上升〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The demand for oil has been rising steadily.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 对石油的需求持续增加。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Living standards have risen dramatically.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 生活水准上升得极快。

Exponent.DEF: to increase, especially gradually over a period of time – used about numbers or amounts
Exponent.TRAN: 增长﹐提高〔尤指在一段时间内逐渐增长﹐用于指数字或数量〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Since 1990, US imports of foreign goods have grown at a rate of 7.7% per year.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 自1990年以来﹐美国的外国商品进口量以每年7.7%的速度增加。

Exponent.DEF: to increase to a high level – used about things that you do not want to increase such as costs, crimes, or violence
Exponent.TRAN: 增加﹐升高〔指达到很高的水平﹐用于费用﹑犯罪或暴力等不希望增加的事物〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Fuel prices are escalating.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 燃料价格不断上涨。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The fighting has escalated.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 战斗升级了。

Exponent.DEF: to become twice as much or three times as much
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Since 1950, the number of people dying from cancer has almost doubled.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 自1950年以来﹐癌症死亡人数几乎增加了一倍。

Exponent.DEF: to become larger in size, or to include a wider range of activities
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The business has expanded at a rate of 15% per year.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司规模以每年15%的速度在扩大。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: We are hoping to expand into mobile phone services.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们希望能扩大到移动电话服务行业。

Exponent.DEF: to increase and reach a very high level – used about numbers and amounts, or about feelings
Exponent.TRAN: 〔尤指数字﹑数量或情绪〕猛增﹐骤增〔指达到很高水平〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The temperature soared to 36.6 degrees centigrade.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 气温急升至36.6摄氏度。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: His confidence soared.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的自信骤增。

Exponent.DEF: to increase very quickly and suddenly – used about prices, numbers, or temperatures
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Share prices shot up 30% over the last week.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 上周股价暴涨了30%。

Section.SECHEADING: TO MAKE SOMETHING INCREASE 使某物增加

Exponent.DEF: to make something larger in number, amount, or degree
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Being overweight increases the risk of having a heart attack.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 体重超标会增加患心脏病的危险。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: We need to increase the number of police officers on the streets.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们需要增加街头巡警的人数。

Exponent.DEF: to increase prices, taxes etc. Put up sth is less formal than increase, and is the usual verb to use in everyday English.
Exponent.TRAN: 提高﹐增加〔不如 increase 正式﹐常用于日常英语〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The landlord has put the rent up again.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 房东再次提高了租金。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: They’re always putting up gas prices.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们老是涨煤气费。

Exponent.DEF: to increase something such as prices or taxes, or levels or standards
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The bank has raised interest rates for the third time this year.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 银行今年已经是第三次提高利率了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The school aims to raise students’ levels of achievement.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这所学校力求提高学生的成绩。

Exponent.DEF: to increase the amount of something so that it is twice or three times as large
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The airline plans to double the number of passengers it carries by 2015.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家航空公司计划到2015年时使乘客人数翻一番。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: High blood pressure triples the risk of strokes.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 高血压使中风的危险增加了两倍。

Exponent.DEF: to increase sales, profits, production etc, especially when they have been lower than you want them to be
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Growing affluence has boosted sales.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 生活日益富足促进了销售。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Oil exports boosted the economy.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 石油出口推动了经济发展。

Exponent.DEF: to increase something so that it contains a wider range of things, or to increase the size of a business
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The company plans to expand its retail operations.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司计划扩展零售业务。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Supermarkets have expanded their ranges to include non-food items.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 超市已把其商品范围扩大到非食品类。

Exponent.DEF: to increase something such as your power or influence, or the number of things you are involved in
Exponent.EXAMPLE: We are hoping to extend the range of services that we offer.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们希望扩大我们的服务范围。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The company plans to extend its dominance of the world car market.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司计划进一步提升其在世界汽车市场上的优势地位。

Exponent.DEF: to increase your efforts or activities, especially to change a situation
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Security has been stepped up following the bombing.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 炸弹袭击发生后安全措施升级。

Exponent.DEF: to increase a feeling or effect
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The attack has heightened concerns about racism in schools.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 此次袭击加重了人们对校园内种族歧视的担忧。

Exponent.DEF: to increase something as much as possible
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Businesses try to maximize efficiency and cut costs.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 企业试图最大限度地提高效率并降低成本。

Sense.DEF: a rise in amount, number, or degree

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an increase in the crime rate
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 犯罪率的上升

Sense.EXAMPLE: Recent tax increases have affected the poor more than the rich.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 新近的增税对穷人的影响比对富人的大。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the dramatic increase in the population aged over 65
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 65岁以上人口的急剧增加
Sense.EXAMPLE: There has been a marked increase in the use of firearms.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 使用枪支的人数显著增加了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Cases of tuberculosis are on the increase.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 结核病病例越来越多。

Sense.DEF: more and more all the time
Sense.TRAN: 不断增加地﹐越来越多地
Sense.EXAMPLE: Marketing techniques are becoming increasingly sophisticated.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 市场营销技巧越来越巧妙。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Increasingly, young people distrust all forms of government.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 年轻人越来越不相信任何形式的政府。

Sense.DEF: extremely good, large, or great
Sense.EXAMPLE: The view is just incredible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 景色美妙至极。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was blood everywhere and the pain was incredible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 到处都是血﹐疼得难以忍受。

Sense.DEF: too strange to be believed, or very difficult to believe
Sense.TRAN: 不可相信的﹐难以置信的
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s incredible that he survived the fall.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他跌下去竟然能够生还﹐真不可思议。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s incredible how much Tom has changed since he met Sally.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 自从遇见萨莉后﹐汤姆的变化之大简直令人难以置信。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I find it almost incredible that no one noticed these errors.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 没人发现这些错误﹐真让我无法相信。

Sense.DEF: extremely
Sense.EXAMPLE: Nicotine is incredibly addictive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尼古丁很容易让人上瘾。

Sense.DEF: in a way that is hard to believe
Sense.EXAMPLE: The knife had pierced his heart, but incredibly he was still alive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 刀插入了他的心脏﹐但他还活着﹐真令人难以置信。

Sense.DEF: a feeling that you cannot believe something
Sense.EXAMPLE: When she told her family she was gay, they reacted with a mixture of shock and incredulity.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当她告诉家人她是同性恋时﹐他们的反应是既震惊又不相信。

Sense.DEF: unable or unwilling to believe something
Sense.TRAN: 不能相信的﹔不愿相信的
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘You sold the car?’ she asked, incredulous.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你把车卖了？”她难以置信地问道。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She shot him an incredulous look.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她满腹狐疑地瞪了他一眼。

Sense.DEF: a regular increase in the amount of money someone is paid
Sense.EXAMPLE: a salary of £18,000, with annual increments of 2.5%
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 工资为18,000英镑﹐每年上涨2.5%

Sense.DEF: the amount by which a number, value, or amount increases
increasing in amount or value gradually and by a regular amount
Sense.EXAMPLE: incremental pay scales
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 递增的工资等级

Sense.DEF: happening gradually over time
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mr Kennedy said that progress on reforms would be incremental.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 肯尼迪先生说改革将逐步进行。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a process of incremental change
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 逐步改变的过程

RunOn.EXAMPLE: You need to make changes in your diet incrementally.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 你需要逐步改变你的日常饮食。

Sense.DEF: a system of making copies of computer files and keeping them safe in case the computer becomes damaged. Only new documents or documents that have changed are copied, because this is quicker than copying all the files every time.
Sense.TRAN: 〔计算机的〕增量备份〔仅对新文件或改动过的文件进行备份﹐这样做比每次复制全部文件快〕

Sense.DEF: to make someone seem guilty of a crime
Sense.TRAN: 使〔某人〕显得有罪﹔连累﹐牵连

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He refused to answer questions for fear he might incriminate himself.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因担心自己可能会受到牵连而拒绝回答。

Sense.DEF: a small group of people in an organization who are fashionable, popular, or powerful, but who do not let many other people join them
Sense.TRAN: 〔时髦﹑受欢迎或有权势但排外的〕小集团﹐小圈子
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was never one of the in-crowd at school.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我上学时从来不属于任何小圈子。

Sense.DEF: if a bird incubates its eggs, or if the eggs incubate, they are kept warm until they hatchthe birds inside are born
if a disease incubates, or if you incubate it, it develops in your body until you show physical signs of it

RunOn.EXAMPLE: Hepatitis has a long incubation period.

Sense.DEF: a piece of hospital equipment into which very small or weak babies are put to keep them alive and warm
Sense.TRAN: 〔放置非常幼小或体弱婴儿的〕恒温箱

Sense.DEF: a heated container for keeping eggs warm until they hatchthe young birds are born
an organization which helps new businesses to develop by giving them office space, services, and equipment, and providing them with business and technical advice
Sense.EXAMPLE: a high-tech incubator on the east coast
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 位于东海岸的高科技企业扶持机构

Sense.DEF: someone or something that causes a lot of worries or problems
Sense.TRAN: 沉重的压力﹔巨大的负担
Sense.EXAMPLE: Joyce regarded his US citizenship as a moral and political incubus.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔伊斯认为他的美国公民身份在道德上和政治上是很大的负担。

Sense.DEF: a male devil that in the past was believed to have sex with a sleeping woman
Sense.TRAN: 梦淫妖〔旧时传说与睡梦中的女人交合的妖怪〕

Sense.DEF: to fix ideas, principles etc in someone’s mind

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I try to inculcate a sense of responsibility in my children.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我试图培养孩子们的责任感。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Not all schools manage to successfully inculcate a love of learning.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不是所有的学校都能培养出学生爱学习的热情。

Sense.DEF: the state of holding an official position, especially in politics, or the time when someone holds an official position
someone who has been elected to an official position, especially in politics, and who is doing that job at the present time
Sense.TRAN: 在职者﹐现任者〔尤指政治职位〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: In the June elections, Morris easily defeated the incumbent, Tom Smith.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在6月的大选中﹐莫里斯轻松击败了在任的汤姆·史密斯。

Sense.LEXUNIT: it is incumbent upon/on sb to do sth
Sense.DEF: if it is incumbent upon you to do something, it is your duty or responsibility to do it
Sense.TRAN: 做某事是某人的职务[责任]
Sense.EXAMPLE: It is incumbent upon parents to control what their children watch on TV.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 控制孩子看什么样的电视节目是父母的责任。

Sense.DEF: the president etc at the present time
Sense.TRAN: 现任总统/现任牧师/本届政府等

Sense.DEF: if you incur a cost, debt, or a fine, you have to pay money because of something you have done
Sense.TRAN: 引致﹐带来 〔成本﹑债务或罚款〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: If the council loses the appeal, it will incur all the legal costs.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果委员会败诉﹐将承担所有诉讼费用。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: the heavy losses incurred by airlines since September 11th
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: “九一一”事件以来航空公司所承受的巨大损失

Sense.DEF: if you incur something unpleasant, it happens to you because of something you have done

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She wondered what she’d done to incur his displeasure this time.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她奇怪她这次做了什么引起他的不悦。

Sense.DEF: impossible to cure

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She has a rare, incurable disease.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她患有一种无法治愈的罕见疾病。

Sense.DEF: impossible to change
Sense.EXAMPLE: an incurable optimist
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不可改变的乐观主义者

Sense.DEF: a sudden attack into an area that belongs to other people

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a combined British and French incursion into China in 1857
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 1857年英法联军入侵中国

Sense.DEF: the sudden arrival of something or someone into a place or activity where they do not belong or have not been before, used especially to say that they are not welcome
Sense.TRAN: 进入﹔〔尤指不受欢迎的〕介入

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The media was criticized for its thoughtless incursion into the domestic grief of the family.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 媒体因不顾他人感受介入该家庭的不幸事件而遭到批评。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: the Japanese incursion into the U.S. domestic electronics market
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 日本进入美国家用电器市场

Sense.DEF: to be very grateful to someone for the help they have given you
Sense.EXAMPLE: We are deeply indebted to Dr Alien.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们非常感谢阿利安博士。

Sense.DEF: owing money to someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: the 17 most heavily indebted nations
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 17个负债最重的国家

Sense.DEF: behaviour that is sexually offensive, especially indecent exposure
Sense.TRAN: 猥亵﹐下流〔尤指猥亵露体〕

Sense.DEF: an action that is shocking or offensive
something that is indecent is shocking and offensive, usually because it involves sex or shows parts of the body that are usually covered
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was found guilty of possessing indecent photographs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被判藏有淫秽照片罪。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can’t go out in that dress – it’s positively indecent!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不能穿那种衣服外出——太不雅观了！

Sense.DEF: completely unacceptable
Sense.EXAMPLE: The funeral formalities were performed with almost indecent haste.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 葬礼草草了事﹐几乎不成体统。

Sense.DEF: the crime of making a sexual attack on someone, touching or threatening to touch them, but not raping them forcing them to have sex
Sense.TRAN: 猥亵罪﹐猥亵侵犯他人身体

Sense.DEF: the criminal offence of deliberately showing your sex organs in a place where this is likely to offend people
Sense.TRAN: 猥亵露体﹐有伤风化的露体〔指故意裸露性器官〕

Sense.DEF: impossible to read or understand
Sense.TRAN: 难以辨认的﹔难以理解的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an indecipherable signature
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 难以辨认的签名

Sense.DEF: the state of being unable to decide what to do
Sense.TRAN: 犹豫不决﹔无决断能力﹔优柔寡断
Sense.EXAMPLE: There were weeks of indecision about who would go and when.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 关于谁去和什么时候去的问题几个星期以来一直悬而未决。

Sense.DEF: unable to make clear decisions or choices
Sense.TRAN: 无决断力的﹐犹豫不决的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a weak and indecisive leader
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个软弱且优柔寡断的领导者

Sense.DEF: not having a clear result
Sense.TRAN: 无确定结果的﹐无决定性的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a confused, indecisive battle
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一场混乱的﹑胜负未决的战斗

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize a statement or answer
Sense.TRAN: 当然﹐确实〔用于强调陈述或回答〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The blood tests prove that Vince is indeed the father.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 验血证明文斯确实是父亲。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Would it help if you had an assistant?’ ‘It would indeed.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你要是有个助手﹐会有帮助吗？”“那是肯定的。

Sense.DEF: used to introduce an additional statement that emphasizes or supports what you have just said
Sense.TRAN: 甚至﹔其实〔用来补充内容﹐以强调或支持刚说过的话〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I didn’t mind at all. Indeed, I was pleased.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一点也不介意﹐事实上我非常高兴。

Sense.DEF: used with ‘very’ and an adjective or adverb to emphasize a statement or description
Sense.TRAN: 真正地 〔与 very 和形容词或副词连用﹐以强调陈述或描述内容〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most of the essays were very good indeed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些文章大多数都非常好。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Thank you very much indeed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 万分感谢。

Sense.DEF: used to show that you are surprised or annoyed by something that someone has just told you
Sense.TRAN: 真的﹐真是〔表示对所听到的消息感到惊讶或恼火〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘He said he was too busy to see you.’ ‘Did he, indeed?’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “他说他太忙﹐没时间见你。”“真的吗？他这么说？”

Sense.DEF: used when someone has asked you a question, to show that you do not know the answer and you do not think there can be a satisfactory answer
Sense.TRAN: 是呀﹐为什么呢？/怎样呢？/谁？等〔表示不知道答案﹐并且认为不会有令人满意的答案〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Why would John have left without saying a word?’ ‘Why indeed?’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “约翰为什么会一句话不说就走了？”“是呀﹐为什么呢？”

Sense.DEF: determined and never giving up
Sense.TRAN: 不屈不挠的﹐坚持不懈的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an indefatigable campaigner for human rights
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不屈不挠的人权运动倡导者

Sense.DEF: too bad to be excused or defended
Sense.TRAN: 不可原谅的﹔无法辩解的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The law is morally indefensible and in need of reform.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这项法令在道德上说不过去﹐需要改进。

Sense.DEF: impossible or very difficult to defend from military attack
Sense.TRAN: 〔对武装攻击〕无法防御的﹐无法保卫的

Sense.DEF: an indefinable feeling, quality etc is difficult to describe or explain
Sense.TRAN: 〔情感﹑品质等〕难以描述的﹔难以解释的
Sense.EXAMPLE: She felt an indefinable sadness.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她感到一种难以名状的悲伤。

Sense.DEF: an indefinite action or period of time has no definite end arranged for it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The next day the union voted to begin an indefinite strike.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 第二天工会投票表决决定开始无限期罢工。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The picture has been loaned for an indefinite period to the National Gallery.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那幅画长期出借给国家美术馆。

Sense.DEF: not clear or exact
Sense.EXAMPLE: Teachers find the report’s terminology so indefinite that it is confusing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老师们发现报告的专门用语含义不明确﹐令人费解。

Sense.DEF: the word ‘a’ or ‘an’
for a period of time for which no definite end has been arranged
Sense.EXAMPLE: The project has been postponed indefinitely.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这项工程被无限期延期。

Sense.DEF: without giving clear or exact details
a word such as ‘some’, ‘any’, or ‘either’ that is used instead of a noun, but does not say exactly which person or thing is meant
Sense.TRAN: 不定代词〔如 some﹐any 或 either〕

Sense.DEF: impossible to remove or forget
Sense.TRAN: 难以去掉的﹔难以忘记的﹔永恒的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her words left an indelible impression on me for years to come.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的话多年来我都难以忘怀。

Sense.DEF: ink etc that makes a permanent mark which cannot be removed
Sense.TRAN: 不褪色墨水/铅笔/记号笔等

RunOn.EXAMPLE: a moment indelibly imprinted on my mind

Sense.DEF: likely to embarrass or shock people
Sense.TRAN: 令人窘迫的﹔令人震惊的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an indelicate comment
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 无礼的评论

Sense.DEF: to promise to pay someone if something they own is damaged or lost
Sense.TRAN: 保证〔遇损坏或损失时〕赔偿

Sense.DEF: to pay someone money because of loss, injury, or damage that they have suffered
Sense.TRAN: 赔偿﹐补偿〔损失﹑伤害或损毁〕

Sense.DEF: protection against loss or damage, especially in the form of a promise to pay for any losses or damage
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指以保证赔偿形式的〕保障
Sense.EXAMPLE: insurance providing indemnity against future liabilities
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对将来的债务提供保障的保险

Sense.DEF: a payment for the loss of money, goods etc
to start a line of writing further towards the middle of the page than other lines
Sense.EXAMPLE: Use the Tab key to indent the first line of the paragraph.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用跳格键把该段的首行缩格。

Sense.DEF: an official order for goods or equipment

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He cancelled the indent for silk scarves.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他取消了真丝围巾的订单。

Sense.DEF: an indentation
a space at the beginning of a line of writing
a cut into the surface or edge of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Make an indentation in the center of each cookie.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在每块甜饼干的中间挖一个缺口。

Sense.DEF: an indented edge or surface has cuts or marks in it
Sense.TRAN: 〔边缘或表面〕呈锯齿状的﹐有凹痕的
Sense.EXAMPLE: our deeply indented coastline
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们蜿蜒曲折的海岸线

Sense.DEF: a formal contract, especially in the past, between an apprentice and his masteremployer, or the act of arranging this
political freedom from control by the government of another country
Sense.TRAN: 独立〔指政治上不受另一国政府控制〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Nigeria gained independence from Britain in I960.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 尼日利亚于1960年脱离英国获得独立。

Sense.DEF: the time when a country becomes politically independent
Sense.TRAN: 独立〔指国家获得独立的那一刻〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The country has made great advances since independence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该国自独立以来发展迅速。

Sense.DEF: the freedom and ability to make your own decisions in life, without having to ask other people for permission, help, or money
Sense.EXAMPLE: ways of helping old people maintain their independence
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 帮助老年人保持独立的方法
Sense.EXAMPLE: Having a job gives you financial independence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有一份工作就能保证经济上的独立。

ColloBox.HEADING: COLLOCATIONS 词语搭配 – Meanings 词义 1 & 2

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The country gained complete independence from Britain in the 1960s.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个国家于20世纪60年代摆脱英国统治﹐获得了完全的独立。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Zambia achieved political independence without a prolonged conflict.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 赞比亚未经长期冲突就获得了政治独立。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The struggle for national independence lasted over 20 years.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这场为争取民族独立的斗争持续了二十多年。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The new constitution aims to strengthen local independence.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条新法规旨在加强地区的独立。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The country eventually got its independence in 1960.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 该国终于在1960年获得独立。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: get independence
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Our aim was to achieve full independence.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们的目标是取得完全的独立。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Estonia declared independence on August 20th.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 爱沙尼亚于8月20日宣布独立。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: allow a country to become independent
Collocate.EXAMPLE: It was General de Gaulle who granted Algeria independence.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 是戴高乐将军准予阿尔及利亚独立。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: gradually achieve it over a period of time
a day on which a country’s independence is celebrated

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The struggle for independence continued for three decades.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这场为争取独立而进行的斗争持续了30年。

Sense.DEF: the day every year on which a country celebrates its independence from another country that controlled it in the past
this day in the US, celebrated on 4th July
an independent organization is not owned or controlled by, or does not receive money from, another organization or the government
Sense.EXAMPLE: There are plans to split the corporation into a number of smaller independent companies.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有计划要把这家大企业分割成一些独立的小公司。
Sense.EXAMPLE: an independent charity
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 独立的慈善机构
Sense.EXAMPLE: small independent bookshops
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 私营小书店

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We need a central bank that is independent of the government.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们需要一个不受政府控制的独立的中央银行。

GramExa.GLOSS: one not owned or paid for by the government

Sense.EXAMPLE: schools in the independent sector
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 私立学校

GramExa.GLOSS: not owned or paid for by the government
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 私营电视台/无线电台/广播等
GramExa.EXAMPLE: independent television companies
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 独立电视公司

GramExa.GLOSS: one not made or produced by a large film production company

Sense.DEF: an independent organization or person is not involved in a particular situation, and can therefore be trusted to be fair in judging it
Sense.TRAN: 独立的﹔公正的﹔无偏见的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an independent panel of scientists
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 独立的科学家小组
Sense.EXAMPLE: An independent body group of people who work together has been set up to monitor government spending.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 成立了一个独立机构来监督政府开支。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There were no independent witnesses to the shooting.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 此次枪击案没有无偏见的证人。

GramExa.GLOSS: carried out by or given by an independent person or organization
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 独立的调查/建议/观点等
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Human rights groups have called for an independent inquiry into the killings.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 人权组织要求对杀戮进行独立调查。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: the results of an independent study
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 独立调查的结果

Sense.DEF: an independent country is not governed or controlled by another country
Sense.EXAMPLE: India became independent in 1947.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 印度于1947年独立。

Subsense.DEF: confident and able to do things by yourself in your own way, without needing help or advice from other people
Subsense.TRAN: 自立的﹐不依赖他人帮助的﹔有主见的
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Now that my sons are more independent, I have more time for myself.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我那几个儿子更加独立了﹐因此我自己的时间就多了。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: an independent young woman
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个有主见的年轻女性
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He’s helping other people with spinal injuries to lead an independent life.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他正在帮助脊椎受伤的人独立生活。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: By this age, the child becomes relatively independent of his mother.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 到了这个年龄﹐孩子可以较为独立﹐不完全依赖母亲。

Subsense.DEF: having enough money to live, without having to ask for help from other people
Subsense.TRAN: 经济自立的﹐自力谋生的
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It was always very important to me to be financially independent.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济独立对我来说始终非常重要。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Robert aimed to be independent of his parents by the time he was twenty.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗伯特的目标是在20岁时脱离父母自立。

Sense.DEF: when you study on your own, rather than being taught by a teacher
Sense.EXAMPLE: The tapes can be used in class or for independent study.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些磁带可在课堂上使用或用于自主学习。

Sense.DEF: someone who has their own income from property, investments etc, so that they do not have to work or depend on anyone else
Sense.TRAN: 〔有个人收入的〕独立女人/男人等

Sense.DEF: if one thing is independent of another, the two are not connected, or the second thing does not influence the first

GramExa.EXAMPLE: reports from two separate sources entirely independent of one another
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 根据两个完全独立的信息来源所作的报道

Sense.EXAMPLE: Three independent studies all arrived at the same conclusion.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 三项独立研究最后都得出了相同的结论。

Sense.DEF: an independent politician does not belong to a particular party
Sense.EXAMPLE: Independent candidates won three seats.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 无党派候选人赢得三个席位。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: The two departments operate independently of each other.
She had elderly parents who could no longer live independently.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的父母年事已高﹐再不能独立生活。

Sense.DEF: a politician who does not belong to a political party
a clause which can make a sentence by itself, for example ‘she went home’ in the sentence ‘She went home because she was tired.’
Sense.TRAN: 独立从句〔即能独立成句的从句﹐如She went home because she was tired中的she went home〕

Sense.DEF: thorough, complete, and considering all the details

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an in-depth study of patients’ needs
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 对病人的需求所作的深入研究
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a series of in-depth interviews
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一系列深入的采访

Sense.DEF: something that is indescribable is so terrible, so good, so strange etc that you cannot describe it, or it is too difficult to describe
Sense.TRAN: 难以名状的﹔无法形容的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a feeling of indescribable joy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 难以言表的喜悦

Sense.DEF: too strong to be destroyed
Sense.TRAN: 不可摧毁的﹔坚不可摧的
Sense.EXAMPLE: her indestructible optimism
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她根深蒂固的乐观主义
Sense.EXAMPLE: Gold is virtually indestructible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 黄金几乎是不可毁坏的。

Sense.DEF: impossible to find out or calculate exactly
Sense.TRAN: 难以查明的﹔无法准确计算的
Sense.EXAMPLE: water of indeterminable depth
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 深不可测的水域

Sense.DEF: impossible to know about definitely or exactly
Sense.TRAN: 难以肯定的﹐无法确定的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a girl of indeterminate age
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 年龄难以确定的女孩

Sense.DEF: an alphabetical list of names, subjects etc at the back of a book, with the numbers of the pages where they can be found
a set of cards or a database containing information, usually arranged in alphabetical order and used especially in a library
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤用于图书馆的〕卡片[资料库]索引

Sense.DEF: a standard by which the level of something can be judged or measured
Sense.TRAN: 〔用于判断或量度水平的〕标志﹐指标

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The changing size of an infant’s head is considered an index of brain growth.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 婴儿头围不断变大标志着大脑在发育。

Sense.DEF: a system by which prices, costs etc can be compared to those of a previous date
Sense.TRAN: 〔用于比较今昔价格﹑费用等的〕指数

Sense.DEF: if documents, information etc are indexed, an index is made for them
Sense.EXAMPLE: The reports are indexed by subject and location.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 报告按主题和位置编索引。

Sense.DEF: to arrange for the level of wages, pensions etc to increase or decrease according to the level of prices
Sense.TRAN: 使〔工资﹑养老金等〕与物价水平挂钩

GramExa.EXAMPLE: demands that wages be indexed to the rise in prices
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 要求工资与物价上涨挂钩

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an amount indexed for inflation
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 和通货膨胀挂钩的数额

Sense.DEF: a small card for writing on, used especially in an index12
the finger next to your thumb
index-linked wages, pensions etc, increase or decrease according to the rise or fall in prices
Sense.TRAN: 〔工资﹑养老金等〕与物价升降挂钩的

Sense.DEF: someone from India
a member of one of the races that lived in North, South, and Central America before the Europeans arrived
a meal of Indian food, or a restaurant that sells Indian food
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you fancy going out for an Indian?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你想出去吃印度菜吗？

Sense.DEF: relating to India or its people
relating to the Indians of North, South, and Central America
a period of warm weather in autumn
Sense.TRAN: 秋季的和暖天气﹐小阳春

Sense.DEF: a happy or successful time, especially near the end of your life or career
Sense.TRAN: 幸福 [成功]的时期〔尤指晚年或事业晚期〕

Sense.DEF: to show that a particular situation exists, or that something is likely to be true

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Research indicates that over 81% of teachers are dissatisfied with their salary.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 研究结果显示超过81%的教师对他们的薪水不满意。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Long skid marks on the pavement indicated the driver had attempted to brake.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 人行道上长长的滑行痕迹表明司机曾试图车。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The study indicates a connection between poverty and crime.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 研究显示贫穷和犯罪有关联。

Sense.DEF: to say or do something to make your wishes, intentions etc clear
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Russians have already indicated their willingness to cooperate.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 俄国人已经表明了愿意合作的意向。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Professor Johnson has indicated his intention to retire at the end of next year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰逊教授表示打算明年年底退休。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Ralph patted the sofa to indicate that she should join him.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 拉尔夫拍拍沙发﹐示意她坐过来。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Please indicate your preference on the booking form.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 请在订单上注明你的偏好。

Sense.DEF: to direct someone’s attention to something or someone, for example by pointing
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘That’s her,’ said Toby, indicating a girl on the other side of the room.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “就是她。”托比指着房间另一端的一个女孩说。

Sense.DEF: to represent something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sales targets are indicated on the graph by a vertical dotted line.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 销售指标在图表中用垂直的虚线表示。

Sense.DEF: to show the direction in which you intend to turn in a vehicle, using lights or your hands
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t forget to indicate before you pull out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 变道前别忘记打转向灯。

Tail.TailContent: Frequencies of the verbs indicate and show in spoken and written English. 动词indicate和show在英语口语和书面语中的使用频率。

This graph shows that show is much more common than indicate in both spoken and written English. This is because show is much more general in meaning and is more commonly used in informal English than indicate. 本图表显示﹐show 在英语口语和书面语中的使用频率都远远高于indicate。这是因为show的语义比较广泛﹐在非正式场合中比indicate更常用。

Sense.DEF: a sign, remark, event etc that shows what is happening, what someone is thinking or feeling, or what is true

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Dark green leaves are a good indication of healthy roots.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 深绿色的树叶充分表明树根长势良好。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He gave no indication at all of his own feelings.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一点也没有显露自己的感情。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Could you give me some indication as to when I am likely to receive a reply?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你能给我透露一下什么时候我能收到回复吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Taking a career history along with you will be a clear indication that you are well organized.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 随身携带履历表﹐这能清楚表明你做事很有条理。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Indications are that the situation hasn’t improved much.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 迹象表明局势并没有多大好转。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There is every indication there are very clear signs that it is true.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 很明显这是真的。

Sense.DEF: the form of a verb that is used to make statements. For example, in the sentences ‘Penny passed her test’, and ‘Michael likes cake’, the verbs ‘passed’ and ‘likes’ are in the indicative.
to be a clear sign that a particular situation exists or that something is likely to be true
Sense.EXAMPLE: This behaviour is indicative of her whole attitude, I’m afraid.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一行为恐怕已表明了她的总体态度。

Sense.DEF: an indicative verb form is used for making statements
something that can be regarded as a sign of something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: All the main economic indicators suggest that trade is improving.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有主要的经济指标都表明贸易情况正在改善。

Sense.DEF: one of the lights on a car that flash to show which way the car is turning
a pointer on a machine that shows the temperature, pressure, speed etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔机器设备中显示温度﹑压力﹑速度等的〕指针

Sense.DEF: a plural of index
to officially charge someone with a criminal offence

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was indicted for vehicular homicide in 1987.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 1987年他因车祸致人死亡被起诉。

Sense.DEF: an indictable offence is one for which you can be indicted
to be a very clear sign that a system, method etc is very bad or very wrong
Sense.TRAN: 是〔制度极不完善﹑方法极其错误等〕的明显征兆
Sense.EXAMPLE: The fact that these children cannot read is a damning indictment of our education system.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些孩子不识字﹐这是对我们教育制度的强烈控诉。

Sense.DEF: an official written statement charging someone with a criminal offence
the act of officially charging someone with a criminal offence
used to refer to popular music that is performed by new bands or singers, and produced by small independent companies
Sense.TRAN: 〔流行音乐〕由新出道的乐队[歌手]演奏[演唱]的﹔由独立的小公司制作的
Sense.EXAMPLE: indie music
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 独立音乐
Sense.EXAMPLE: an indie band
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 独立乐队

Sense.DEF: a small independent company, especially one that produces popular music
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指制作流行音乐的〕小型独立公司

Sense.DEF: lack of interest or concern

GramExa.EXAMPLE: his apparent indifference to material luxuries
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他对物质享受明显缺乏兴趣

Sense.EXAMPLE: Whether you stay or leave is a matter of total indifference to me I do not care.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你是留是走我根本无所谓。

Sense.DEF: not at all interested in someone or something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Sarah was absolutely indifferent to him, and it hurt.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 萨拉对他漠不关心﹐这令他伤心。

Sense.DEF: not particularly good
Sense.TRAN: 不太好的﹐一般的﹐平庸的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an indifferent cook
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 手艺平平的厨师

Sense.DEF: indigenous people or things have always been in the place where they are, rather than being brought there from somewhere else

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Blueberries are indigenous to America.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 蓝莓原产于美洲。

Sense.EXAMPLE: the many indigenous cultures which existed in Siberia
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 存在于西伯利亚的许多当地文化

Sense.DEF: very poor
food that is indigestible cannot easily be broken down in the stomach into substances that the body can use
information that is indigestible is not easy to understand
Sense.EXAMPLE: indigestible statistics
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看不懂的统计数字

Sense.DEF: pain that you get when your stomach cannot break down food that you have eaten
angry and surprised because you feel insulted or unfairly treated
Sense.TRAN: 〔由于感觉受辱或受到不公平待遇而〕气愤的﹐愤慨的﹐愤愤不平的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Liz was indignant at the way her child had been treated.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利兹对自己孩子受到的待遇非常气愤。

Sense.EXAMPLE: an indignant reply
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 愤慨的回复

RunOn.EXAMPLE: ‘Of course I didn’t tell her!’ Sasha said indignantly.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: “我当然没有告诉她！”萨莎气愤地说。

Sense.DEF: feelings of anger and surprise because you feel insulted or unfairly treated
Sense.TRAN: 〔因感觉受辱或受到不公平待遇而产生的〕愤慨﹐义愤﹐愤怒
Sense.EXAMPLE: To his indignation, Charles found that his name was not on the list.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 查尔斯发现他的名字没有出现在名单上﹐这让他深感愤慨。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Lou’s voice quivered with indignation.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 洛乌气得说话声都颤抖了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Her indignation at such rough treatment was understandable.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 遭受如此粗暴的待遇﹐她大为光火是可以理解的。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He stormed into her office, full of righteous indignation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他义愤填膺﹐气呼呼地冲进她的办公室。

Sense.DEF: a situation that makes you feel very ashamed and not respected
Sense.EXAMPLE: The prisoners were subjected to all sorts of indignities.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 犯人遭受各种侮辱。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Two of the diplomats suffered the indignity of being arrested.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 那些外交官中有两名蒙受了被捕之辱。

Sense.DEF: a dark purple-blue colour
not directly caused by something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Losing weight is an indirect result of smoking cigarettes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吸烟间接导致体重减轻。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The indirect effects of climate change may be profound.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 气候变化造成的间接影响可能是深远的。

Sense.DEF: an indirect way to a place is not the straightest way
Sense.EXAMPLE: They took an indirect route, avoiding the town centre.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们绕路走﹐避开了市中心。

Sense.DEF: not saying or showing something in a clear definite way
Sense.EXAMPLE: George’s comments were an indirect way of blaming me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔治的评论转弯抹角地指责了我。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: Perhaps I was indirectly responsible for the misunderstanding.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 也许我应为这个误解承担间接责任。

Sense.DEF: money that a business must spend, not directly on its products or services, but on other things such as buildings or wages
an object of a verb that refers to the person that something is given to, said to, made for etc. For example, in the sentence ‘I asked him a question’, the indirect object is ‘him’.
Sense.TRAN: 间接宾语〔如I asked him a question中的him〕

Sense.DEF: a way of reporting what someone said without repeating their exact words. For example, in the sentence ‘Julia said that she didn’t want to go’, the clause ‘that she didn’t want to go’ is indirect speech. Her actual words were ‘I don’t want to go’.
Sense.TRAN: 间接引语〔即不引用原话﹐如Julia said that she didn’t want to go中that she didn’t want to go为间接引语﹔Julia的原话是I don’t want to go〕

Sense.DEF: a tax which is added to the cost of goods and services
very difficult to see, hear, or notice
Sense.TRAN: 难以看到的﹔难以听见的﹔难以察觉的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The path was almost indiscernible in the mist.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 迷雾中小路依稀难辨。

Sense.DEF: a lack of control in the behaviour of a group of people, with the result that they behave badly
Sense.EXAMPLE: Indiscipline among the troops eventually led to a riot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 军纪不严最终导致了骚乱。

Sense.DEF: careless about what you say or do, especially by talking about things which should be kept secret
Sense.TRAN: 〔说话﹑行事〕轻率的﹐不慎重的〔尤指泄露机密〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was very indiscreet of Colin to tell them about our plan.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 科林把我们的计划告诉了他们﹐太不谨慎了。

Sense.DEF: an action or remark that shows a lack of good judgment, especially one that is morally unacceptable
Sense.TRAN: 不谨慎的言行﹔〔尤指道德上〕有失检点的言行
Sense.EXAMPLE: Earl describes his past links with the racist group as a youthful indiscretion.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 厄尔认为他过去和种族主义团体有联系是年少不懂事。
Sense.EXAMPLE: rumours of the former president’s sexual indiscretions
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 关于前总统性生活不检点的谣传

Sense.DEF: an indiscriminate action is done without thinking about what harm it might cause
Sense.TRAN: 不分青红皂白的﹐不加区分的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: terrorists responsible for indiscriminate killing
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 应为滥杀无辜负责的恐怖分子

Sense.EXAMPLE: the indiscriminate use of chemical fertilizers
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 化肥的滥用

RunOn.EXAMPLE: Soldiers fired indiscriminately into the crowd.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 士兵们不分青红皂白地向群众开枪。

Sense.DEF: someone or something that is indispensable is so important or useful that it is impossible to manage without them

GramExa.EXAMPLE: This book is indispensable to anyone interested in space exploration.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 本书是任何对太空探险感兴趣的人必读的。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Meat is not indispensable for maintaining a healthy diet.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 要想健康饮食﹐肉食并不是不可或缺的。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Mobile phones have become an indispensable part of our lives.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 移动电话已经成为我们生活中的必需品。

Sense.DEF: ill and therefore unable to be present
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mrs Rawlins is temporarily indisposed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 罗林斯太太临时因身体不适不能出席。

Sense.DEF: not willing to do something
a slight illness
an indisputable fact must be accepted because it is definitely true
Sense.TRAN: 无可争辩的﹐不容置疑的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The evidence was indisputable.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个证据不容置疑。

Sense.DEF: an indissoluble relationship cannot be destroyed
Sense.EXAMPLE: the indissoluble link between language and culture
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 语言和文化的紧密关系

Sense.DEF: an indistinct sound, image, or memory cannot be seen, heard, or remembered clearly
Sense.TRAN: 〔声音﹑影像或记忆〕不清楚的﹐模糊的
Sense.EXAMPLE: She muttered something indistinct.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她含含糊糊地嘟哝了句什么。
Sense.EXAMPLE: My memory of what happened next is indistinct.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 接下来发生了什么我都不记得了。

Sense.DEF: things that are indistinguishable are so similar that you cannot see any difference between them
Sense.TRAN: 难以分辨的﹐难以区分的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an artificial material that is almost indistinguishable from real silk
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 与真丝几乎无法区分的人造材料

Sense.DEF: considered separately from other people or things in the same group
Sense.EXAMPLE: Each individual leaf on the tree is different.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 树上每片叶子都不相同。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the needs of the individual customer
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 每位顾客的需求

Sense.DEF: belonging to or intended for one person rather than a group
Sense.EXAMPLE: Children get more individual attention in small classes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小班上课的孩子得到较多的个别关注。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can have the bathroom designed to suit your individual needs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以让人按照你的个人需要来设计浴室。
Sense.EXAMPLE: individual portions of jam
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一人份果酱

Sense.DEF: an individual style, way of doing things etc is different from anyone else’s – usually used to show approval
Sense.TRAN: 〔风格﹑做事方式等〕独特的﹐与众不同的〔一般含褒义〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a tennis player with a highly individual style
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 风格非常独特的网球选手
Sense.EXAMPLE: a very individual way of dressing
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 非常有个性的衣着方式

Sense.DEF: a person, considered separately from the rest of the group or society that they live in
Sense.EXAMPLE: the rights of the individual
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 个人权利
Sense.EXAMPLE: Each individual receives two genes, one inherited from each parent.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 每个人都有两种基因﹐分别来自父亲和母亲。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most churches were built with donations from private individuals ordinary people, rather than the government or companies.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数教堂都是由私人捐款建成的。

Sense.DEF: a person of a particular kind, especially one who is unusual in some way
Sense.TRAN: 有某种特点的人〔尤指在某些方面与众不同的人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a strange-looking individual
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个长相怪异的人

Sense.DEF: the belief that the rights and freedom of individual people are the most important rights in a society
Sense.TRAN: 个人主义〔视个人权利和自由至上的信仰〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Capitalism encourages competition and individualism.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 资本主义鼓励竞争﹐提倡个人主义。

Sense.DEF: the behaviour or attitude of someone who does things in their own way without being influenced by other people
someone who does things in their own way and has different opinions from most other people
Sense.TRAN: 我行我素的人﹐特立独行的人
Sense.EXAMPLE: Geoff was too much of an individualist to be team captain.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 杰夫过于我行我素﹐没法当队长。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: She has a highly individualistic approach to painting.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 她有自己一套独特的绘画方法。

Sense.DEF: the qualities that make someone or something different from other things or people
Sense.EXAMPLE: We like our staff to show their individuality rather than wear a uniform.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们喜欢员工穿出个性﹐而不是穿制服。

Sense.DEF: designed to fit the special needs of a particular person or thing
Sense.TRAN: 个性化的﹐切合个人[个体]需要的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an individualized training program
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 个性化培训方案

Sense.DEF: separately, not together in a group
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bridegroom thanked them all individually.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 新郎向他们一一道谢。
Sense.EXAMPLE: individually wrapped portions of cheese
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 独立包装的一份份干酪

Sense.DEF: to make someone or something clearly different from others of the same kind
Sense.EXAMPLE: The characters in the play are beautifully individuated.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 剧中人物个性鲜明﹐处理得极为得体。

Sense.DEF: to have an idea of yourself as an independent person, separate from other people
something that is indivisible cannot be separated or divided into parts
Indian and something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: Indo-European languages
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 印欧语(系)

Sense.DEF: to train someone to accept a particular set of beliefs, especially political or religious ones, and not consider any others
Sense.TRAN: 向〔某人〕灌输〔信仰﹐尤指政治或宗教思想〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: People were indoctrinated not to question their leaders.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人们被灌输对领导人不得置疑的观念。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: The military in particular were subjected to intense political indoctrination.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 军队尤其受到大量的政治思想灌输。

Sense.DEF: the Indo-European group of languages includes English, French, Hindi, Russian, and most of the other languages of Europe and northern India
Sense.TRAN: 印欧语系的〔印欧语系包括英语﹑法语﹑印地语﹑俄语以及大多数欧洲其他语言和印度北部的语言〕

Sense.DEF: lazy
having great determination or courage
Sense.EXAMPLE: an indomitable old lady
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 勇敢的老妇人

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Alice was a woman of indomitable spirit.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 艾丽斯是一个意志坚强的女人。

Sense.DEF: used or happening inside a building
Sense.EXAMPLE: an indoor swimming pool
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 室内游泳池
Sense.EXAMPLE: the world indoor athletics championship
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 世界室内田径锦标赛
Sense.EXAMPLE: Too much central heating can harm indoor plants.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 中央供暖系统温度太高对室内植物有害。

F2NBox.HEADING: GRAMMAR 语法: indoor, indoors
F2NBox.EXPL: Indoor is an adjective and indoors is an adverb.
F2NBox.TRAN: indoor是形容词﹐indoors则是副词
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: I stayed indoors(NOT不说indoor).
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 我待在屋内。
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: indoor sports(NOT不说indoors sports)
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 室内体育项目

Sense.DEF: into or inside a building
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s go indoors and have something to eat.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们进屋吃点东西吧。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It rained all day so we had to stay indoors.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 雨下了整整一天﹐我们只好留在屋里。

Sense.DEF: another spelling of endorse
air that someone breathes in a way that can be heard, especially because they are shocked
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指惊慌时〕吸入的[倒吸的]一口气
Sense.EXAMPLE: She heard Mitch’s swiftly indrawn breath.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她听见米奇快速地倒吸了一口气。

Sense.DEF: certainly or without doubt
Sense.TRAN: 不容置疑地﹐毫无疑问地
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mr Sachs is indubitably charming.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 毫无疑问萨克斯先生很有魅力。

Sense.DEF: to persuade someone to do something, especially something that does not seem wise
Sense.TRAN: 劝诱﹐诱导〔尤指做似乎不明智的事〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Nothing would induce me to vote for him again.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 没有什么能诱使我再投他的票了。

Sense.DEF: to make a woman give birth to her baby by giving her a special drug
Sense.EXAMPLE: She had to be induced because the baby was four weeks late.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的孩子晚了四星期仍未出生﹐因此要给她引产。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The doctor decided to induce labour.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 医生决定引产。

Sense.DEF: to cause a particular physical condition
Sense.EXAMPLE: Patients with eating disorders may use drugs to induce vomiting.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 患有进食障碍的人可使用药物催吐。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a drug-induced coma
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 药物引起的昏迷

Sense.DEF: a reason for doing something, especially something that you will get as a result

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Businesses were offered inducements to move to the area.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 企业被吸引搬迁到该地区。

Sense.EXAMPLE: financial inducements to attract good job candidates
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吸引优秀人才前来应征的经济诱因

Sense.DEF: to officially give someone a job or position of authority, especially at a special ceremony

GramExa.EXAMPLE: 18 new junior ministers were inducted into the government.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 18位资历较浅的新部长正式就任政府职务。

Sense.DEF: to officially introduce someone into a group or organization, especially the army
Sense.TRAN: 正式吸收…为成员﹔〔尤指〕征召…入伍

Sense.DEF: to officially introduce someone into an important place of honour at a special ceremony

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Barry was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1987.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 巴里于1987年被列入篮球名人堂。

Sense.DEF: someone who is joining a special group, especially the army
the introduction of someone into a new job, company, official position etc, or the ceremony at which this is done

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a two-day induction course
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 为期两天的入门课程

Sense.EXAMPLE: Mrs Simpson is responsible for the induction of new library staff.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 辛普森太太负责图书馆新职员的入职培训。

Sense.DEF: the process of making a woman give birth to her baby by giving her a special drug
the production of electricity in one object by another that already has electrical or magnetic power
a process of thought that uses known facts to produce general rules or principles
a piece of electrical equipment that changes a low voltage to a higher one
Sense.TRAN: 感应(线)圈〔用于增加电压〕

Sense.DEF: using known facts to produce general principles
Sense.EXAMPLE: inductive reasoning
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 归纳推理

Sense.DEF: connected with electrical or magnetic induction
to let yourself do or have something that you enjoy, especially something that is considered bad for you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Most of us were too busy to indulge in heavy lunchtime drinking.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们大多数人都忙得不能在午饭时尽情饮酒。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Eva had never been one to indulge in self-pity.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 伊娃从不是那种沉湎于自怜自哀的人。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Even if you’re dieting, you can indulge yourself eat what you want once in a while.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 即使在节食﹐也可以偶尔放纵一下。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Ray has enough money to indulge his taste for expensive wines.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 雷有足够的钱来尽情享受高档葡萄酒。

Sense.DEF: to let someone have or do whatever they want, even if it is bad for them
Sense.EXAMPLE: His mother spoiled him, indulging his every whim.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他母亲对他纵容娇惯﹐百依百顺。

Sense.DEF: to take part in an activity, especially an illegal one
Sense.TRAN: 参与﹐参加〔尤指违法活动〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Women do not indulge in crime to the same extent as men.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 女性参与犯罪的程度与男性不同。

Sense.DEF: the habit of allowing yourself to do or have whatever you want, or allowing someone else to do or have whatever they want
something that you do or have for pleasure, not because you need it
Sense.EXAMPLE: An occasional glass of wine was his only indulgence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 偶尔喝杯葡萄酒是他唯一的嗜好。

Sense.DEF: willingness to ignore someone’s faults or weaknesses
Sense.EXAMPLE: a spirit of indulgence and forgiveness
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 包容和宽恕的精神

Sense.DEF: a promise of freedom from punishment by God, sold by priests in the Middle Ages
Sense.TRAN: 〔欧洲中世纪由神父出售的〕赎罪券﹐赦罪符

Sense.DEF: willing to allow someone, especially a child, to do or have whatever they want, even if this is not good for them
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指对孩子〕溺爱的﹐纵容的﹐放纵的
Sense.EXAMPLE: toys bought by their indulgent grandparents
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 溺爱孩子的(外)祖父母买的玩具

Sense.DEF: relating to industry or the people working in it

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Industrial production has risen by 0.5% since November.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 11月份以来工业产量提高了0.5%。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: rapid post-war industrial development
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 战后工业的快速发展

GramExa.GLOSS: disagreement between workers and their employers
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 劳资冲突/劳资纠纷/产业工人的骚乱
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Last year 1.3 million workers took part in industrial disputes.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年有130万名工人牵涉入劳资纷争。

GramExa.GLOSS: happening at work

Sense.DEF: having many industries
Sense.TRAN: 有很多工业的﹐工业发达的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a meeting of the world’s major industrial nations
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 世界主要工业国参加的会议

GramExa.EXAMPLE: pollution in industrial areas
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 工业区的污染

Sense.EXAMPLE: By 1900, Britain was a mainly industrial society.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 到1900年英国已基本进入工业社会。

Sense.DEF: of the type used in industry
Sense.EXAMPLE: cleaning products that are for industrial use only not to be used at home
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 仅限工业用的清洁产品

Sense.DEF: an action such as a strikestopping work taken by workers involved in a disagreement with their employer
the study of old factories, machines etc
Sense.TRAN: 工业考古学〔研究早期工厂﹑机器等〕

Sense.DEF: a subject taught in school about how to use tools, machinery etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔学校中教授怎样使用工具﹑机器等的〕工艺课

Sense.DEF: stealing secret information from one company in order to help another company
a piece of land, often on the edge of a town, where there are factories and businesses
the system by which a society gets its wealth through industries and machinery
Sense.TRAN: 工业主义﹐产业主义〔指主要依靠工业和机械获得财富的体制〕

Sense.DEF: a person who owns or runs a factory or industrial company
when a country or place develops a lot of industry
an industrialized country or place has a lot of factories, mines etc
the relationship between workers and employers
the period in the 18th and 19th centuries in Europe and the US when machines were invented and the first factories were established
Sense.TRAN: 工业革命﹐产业革命〔指欧洲和美国在18和19世纪发明机器﹑建立第一批工厂的时期〕

Sense.DEF: an industrial-strength substance is very strong – often used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 强烈的﹔浓烈的﹔强效的〔常为幽默用法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: They served us industrial-strength coffee.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们给我们端上味道浓郁的咖啡。

Sense.DEF: a court that judges disagreements between workers and their employers
someone who is industrious works hard

Subsense.DEF: the large-scale production of goods or of substances such as coal and steel
Subsense.EXAMPLE: This type of software is widely used in industry.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种软件广泛应用于工业。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: workers in manufacturing industry
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 制造业工人

Subsense.DEF: the people who work in industry
Subsense.EXAMPLE: an agreement that will be welcomed by both sides of industry employers and workers
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 将受到劳资双方欢迎的协定

Sense.DEF: businesses that produce a particular type of thing or provide a particular service
Sense.EXAMPLE: I work in the oil industry.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在石油行业工作。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Italy’s thriving tourist industry
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 意大利蓬勃发展的旅游业

Sense.DEF: the fact of working hard
Sense.EXAMPLE: Gould is a man of great industry.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 古尔德是一个很勤劳的人。

Sense.DEF: an area of work which has grown too large – used to show disapproval
Sense.TRAN: 范围﹐领域﹐界〔指规模过大﹐含贬义〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: another book from the Shakespeare industry
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 庞杂的莎士比亚研究领域的又一部专著

ColloBox.HEADING: COLLOCATIONS 词语搭配 – MEANINGS 义项 1 & 2

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Agriculture is still a major industry in Scotland.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 在苏格兰农业仍是主要产业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: one that is doing very well
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Software development soon became a thriving industry in the area.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 软件开发很快成了该地区兴旺的行业。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Tourism is a growing industry in the many parts of the developing world.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 旅游业是许多发展中国家迅速增长的行业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: one that is doing badly
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Coal and steel are declining industries in Britain.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 英国的煤炭业和炼钢业在走下坡路。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: industries in which goods are produced in factories
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The last twenty years has seen a decline in manufacturing industry.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 制造业在过去的20年里衰退了。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: businesses that provide a service, such as banking and tourism
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Most of the new jobs are in service industries.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 新的工作岗位大部分都在服务行业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: industries that involve the production of large goods
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Shipbuilding and other heavy industry developed in the North of Britain.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 造船及其他重工业在英国北部发展起来。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: industries that involve the production of small goods
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Jobs in light industry are increasing.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 轻工业的工作岗位在增加。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Modern industry needs to be in places where there are good transport links.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 现代工业需要地处交通便捷的地方。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: an industry that has been in a particular area for a long time
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The shipyards, the traditional industry in the north east, had closed.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些属于东北部传统工业的造船厂关闭了。

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 煤炭工业/汽车工业/纺织工业等
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The town was very dependant on the car industry.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 该城镇很依赖汽车工业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: the work of producing films or music

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The clothing industry grew rapidly during the 1960s. 20
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 世纪60年代制衣业快速发展。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: becomes less successful
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The shipping industry declined after World War II.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 第二次世界大战后航运业衰落了。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: More investment is needed to develop new industries such as tourism.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 发展诸如旅游业等新兴产业需要更多的投资。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Financial scandals have damaged the industry in recent years.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 近年来财务丑闻损害了这一行业。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: make it owned by the state
make it privately owned, rather than owned by the state
control an industry so that it does not make unfair profits
one of the most successful companies in a particular industry
Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 行业领头羊﹐行业领头企业
Collocate.EXAMPLE: We are now a mature company and an industry leader.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们现在是一家成熟的公司和行业领头羊。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: people who know a lot about a particular industry
people who study a particular industry to see how it is developing
someone who runs a large company and has a lot of influence
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He rose to be a great captain of industry.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他成为了不起的业界巨头。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: producing goods, and buying and selling them
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He works for the Department of Trade and Industry.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在工业与贸易署工作。

Sense.DEF: in-ear headphones fit inside your ear
drunk
if something is inedible, you cannot eat it because it tastes bad or is poisonous
Sense.EXAMPLE: The meat was so burnt that it was inedible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 肉烧得那么焦﹐不能吃了。

Sense.DEF: impossible or very difficult to educate
Sense.TRAN: 不可教育的﹔难以教育的

Sense.DEF: too great to be described in words
Sense.TRAN: 〔好得〕难以名状的﹐不可言喻的
Sense.EXAMPLE: ineffable joy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 难以形容的喜悦

Sense.DEF: something that is ineffective does not achieve what it is intended to achieve
Sense.TRAN: 无效果的﹐不起作用的﹐不奏效的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The chemical was almost totally ineffective in killing the weeds.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种化学品除杂草几乎一点用也没有。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Various drugs have proved ineffective against the virus.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多药物经证明都对这种病毒无效。

Sense.EXAMPLE: an ineffective marketing campaign
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一场毫无成效的营销活动

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday English, people usually say that something does not work rather than saying that it is ineffective .
F2NBox.TRAN: 日常英语中一般说do not work﹐而不说be ineffective
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: These drugs don’t work against bird flu.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些药对禽流感无效。

Sense.DEF: not having the ability, confidence, or personal authority to get things done
Sense.TRAN: 无能力的﹔无信心的﹔无威望的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an ineffectual leader
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 无能的领导人
Sense.EXAMPLE: She remembered her ineffectual efforts to comfort him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她记得自己曾努力去安慰他﹐但徒劳无功。

Sense.DEF: not using time, money, energy etc in the best way
Sense.EXAMPLE: an inefficient use of resources
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 资源的浪费
Sense.EXAMPLE: Local government was inefficient.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地方政府效率低下。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: problems due to the inefficiency of management

Sense.DEF: not graceful or attractive
Sense.EXAMPLE: an inelegant expression
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 粗俗的表达方式

Sense.DEF: not allowed to have or do something because of a law or rule
Sense.TRAN: 〔按法律或规定〕无资格的﹐不合格的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Temporary workers are ineligible for the pension scheme.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 临时工没有资格参加养老金计划。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: People under 18 are ineligible to vote.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 18岁以下者无投票资格。

Sense.DEF: impossible to avoid
not good at doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: inept leadership
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 拙劣的领导
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was criticized for his inept handling of the problem.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因处理这个问题不力而遭到批评。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Blake was intellectually able but politically inept.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 布莱克头脑很聪明﹐但在政治上却十分愚钝。

Sense.DEF: lack of skill
Sense.EXAMPLE: the ineptitude of the people in charge
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 主管的无能

Sense.DEF: an unfair situation, in which some groups in society have more money, opportunities, power etc than others

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There are inequalities in wealth distribution.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 财富分配不平等。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: inequality of opportunity
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 机遇的不均

GramExa.EXAMPLE: inequalities between men and women
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 男女间的不平等

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a policy that aims to redress racial inequalities
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 旨在纠正种族不平等的政策

Sense.DEF: not equally fair to everyone
Sense.EXAMPLE: an inequitable distribution of wealth
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 财富分配的不平等

Sense.DEF: lack of fairness, or something that is unfair

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the inequities of the legal system
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 法律制度的不公正

GramExa.EXAMPLE: inequities in the distribution of research funding
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 研究基金的分配不公

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a report on racial inequity in the UK
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 关于英国种族不平等的报告

Sense.DEF: impossible to change or remove
Sense.TRAN: 难以根除的﹐根深蒂固的
Sense.EXAMPLE: ineradicable hostility
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 根深蒂固的敌意

Sense.DEF: not producing a chemical reaction when combined with other substances
Sense.EXAMPLE: inert gases
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 惰性气体

Sense.DEF: not moving, or not having the strength or power to move
Sense.TRAN: 不动的﹔无行动能力的﹔无力活动的
Sense.EXAMPLE: He lay, inert, in his bed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一动不动地躺在床上。

Sense.DEF: not willing to do anything
Sense.EXAMPLE: The government was inert and inefficient.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府毫无活力﹐效率低下。

Sense.DEF: when no one wants to do anything to change a situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: political inertia
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政治上的保守

Sense.DEF: the force that keeps an object in the same position or keeps it moving until it is moved or stopped by another force
a lack of energy and a feeling that you do not want to do anything
an inescapable fact or situation is one that you cannot avoid or ignore
Sense.TRAN: 不可避免的﹔不容忽视的
Sense.EXAMPLE: She didn’t want to confront the inescapable fact that she would have to sell the house.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她不想面对必须卖掉房子这一无法逃避的事实。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The inescapable conclusion is that he was murdered by someone in his own family.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 必然的结论就是: 他是被自己的家人谋杀的。

Sense.DEF: not needed
Sense.EXAMPLE: inessential details
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不必要的细节

Sense.DEF: too much or too great to be calculated
Sense.TRAN: 〔由于太多或太大而〕难以计算的﹐无法估计的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a painting of inestimable value
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一幅价值连城的画

Sense.DEF: the fact that something is certain to happen, or something that is certain to happen
Sense.TRAN: 必然性﹔必然发生的事﹐不可避免的事

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the inevitability of death
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 死亡的必然性

Sense.DEF: certain to happen and impossible to avoid
Sense.TRAN: 必然发生的﹐不可避免的
Sense.EXAMPLE: A further escalation of the crisis now seems inevitable.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 危机的进一步升级现在看来已不可避免。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It’s inevitable that doctors will make the occasional mistake.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 医生偶尔犯错是难免的。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Disease was an inevitable consequence of poor living conditions.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 恶劣的生活条件必然诱发疾病。

Sense.DEF: a situation that is certain to happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: One day the inevitable happened and I got a speeding ticket.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有一天﹐不可避免的事情发生了: 我收到了一张超速罚款单。

Sense.DEF: used for saying that something is certain to happen and cannot be avoided
Sense.EXAMPLE: The decision will inevitably lead to political tensions.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该决定必然导致政治局势的紧张。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Inevitably, the situation did not please everyone.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种状况必定不能让所有人都感到满意。

Sense.DEF: not exact
Sense.EXAMPLE: Earthquake prediction is an inexact science.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地震预测是一门不精确的科学。

Sense.DEF: inexcusable behaviour is too bad to be excused
Sense.TRAN: 不可原谅的﹐不可宽恕的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an inexcusable act of aggression
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不可饶恕的侵略行为

Sense.DEF: something that is inexhaustible exists in such large amounts that it can never be finished or used up
Sense.EXAMPLE: She has an inexhaustible supply of funny stories.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她有讲不完的有趣故事。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a man of inexhaustible energy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 精力无穷的人

Sense.DEF: an inexorable process cannot be stopped
Sense.TRAN: 不可阻挡的﹐不可更改的
Sense.EXAMPLE: the inexorable decline of Britain’s manufacturing industry
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 英国制造业无可挽回的衰落
Sense.EXAMPLE: the seemingly inexorable rise in crime
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 似乎无法遏止的犯罪率上升势头

Sense.DEF: cheap – use this to show approval
Sense.TRAN: 不昂贵的﹐价钱公道的〔含褒义〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a good selection of inexpensive wines
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 可供选择的各种价格公道的葡萄酒
Sense.EXAMPLE: Painting is a relatively inexpensive way to enhance your home.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 粉刷是美化居室的一种相对较便宜的方式。

Sense.DEF: lack of experience
Sense.EXAMPLE: youthful inexperience
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 少不更事

Sense.DEF: not having had much experience
Sense.EXAMPLE: inexperienced pilots
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经验不足的飞行员

Sense.DEF: not having the skill to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: an inexperienced and inexpert teacher
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个经验不足﹑业务不熟练的老师

Sense.DEF: too unusual or strange to be explained or understood
Sense.TRAN: 〔由于太不寻常或奇怪而〕无法解释的﹐费解的
Sense.EXAMPLE: inexplicable behaviour
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 费解的行为
Sense.EXAMPLE: For some inexplicable reason, he felt depressed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他无端地感到很沮丧。

Sense.DEF: an inexpressible feeling is too strong to be described in words
Sense.TRAN: 〔情感过于强烈而〕难以言传的
Sense.EXAMPLE: inexpressible gratitude
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 难以言表的感谢

Sense.DEF: a face that is inexpressive shows no emotion
in a very difficult situation when you need to do something very extreme
at the moment of death
two or more things that are inextricable are closely related and affect each other
Sense.EXAMPLE: the inextricable connection between language and culture
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 语言和文化之间密不可分的联系

Sense.DEF: if two or more things are inextricably linked etc, they are very closely related and affect each other
Sense.EXAMPLE: Physical health is inextricably linked to mental health.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 身体健康和精神健康有着密不可分的联系。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Economic and social history are inextricably bound up with each other.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济发展史和社会发展史紧密相关。

Sense.DEF: always right and never making mistakes
Sense.TRAN: 永远正确的﹐从不犯错误的
Sense.EXAMPLE: No expert is infallible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 没有一个专家永远正确。
Sense.EXAMPLE: an infallible memory
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 绝对可靠的记忆

Sense.DEF: something that is infallible always works or has the intended effect
Sense.EXAMPLE: He had an infallible cure for a hangover.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他有对付宿醉绝对灵验的良方。

Sense.DEF: well known for being bad or evil
Sense.TRAN: 声名狼藉的﹐臭名昭著的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an infamous killer
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 臭名昭著的杀手
Sense.EXAMPLE: Los Angeles’ infamous smog
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 恶名远播的洛杉矶雾霾

GramExa.EXAMPLE: This area is infamous for drugs and prostitution.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个地区因毒品和卖淫而声名狼藉。

Sense.DEF: the state of being evil or well known for evil things
Sense.TRAN: 丑恶﹔恶名昭彰﹐声名狼藉

Sense.DEF: the period of a child’s life before they can walk or talk

GramExa.EXAMPLE: In the past, many children died in infancy.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 过去很多孩子尚在襁褓之中便夭折了。

Sense.DEF: the time when something is just starting to be developed
Sense.EXAMPLE: the infancy of radio broadcasting
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 无线电广播的初期阶段
Sense.EXAMPLE: Genetic engineering is still in its infancy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 基因工程学仍处于起步阶段。

Sense.DEF: a baby or very young child
Sense.EXAMPLE: An infant’s skin is very sensitive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 幼儿的皮肤非常敏感。

Sense.DEF: children in school in Britain between the ages of four and eight
Sense.TRAN: 〔英国学校里四至八岁的〕学童

Sense.DEF: a school, teacher etc for children aged between four and eight in Britain
Sense.TRAN: 〔英国教授四至八岁儿童的〕儿童学校/教师/班级等

Sense.DEF: intended for babies or very young children
Sense.EXAMPLE: infant formula milk
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 婴(幼)儿配方奶

Sense.DEF: an infant company, organization etc has just started to exist or be developed
Sense.TRAN: 〔公司﹑组织等〕刚成立的﹐初创的
Sense.EXAMPLE: infant industries
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 新兴工业

Sense.DEF: the crime of killing a child
infantile behaviour seems silly in an adult because it is typical of a child
Sense.EXAMPLE: infantile jokes
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 幼稚的玩笑

Sense.DEF: relating to or affecting babies and very young children
Sense.EXAMPLE: infantile development
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 婴幼儿的发育

Sense.TRAN: 脊髓灰质炎﹐小儿麻痹症

Sense.DEF: the number of deaths of babies under one year old, expressed as the number out of every 1,000 babies born alive in a year
Sense.TRAN: 婴儿死亡率〔以每年每1,000名新生婴儿为统计单位〕

Sense.DEF: soldiers who fight on foot
Sense.EXAMPLE: an infantry regiment
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 步兵团

Sense.DEF: a soldier who fights on foot
having strong feelings of love for someone or a strong interest in something that makes you unable to think in a sensible way

GramExa.EXAMPLE: John had become infatuated with the French teacher.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰迷恋上了那位法语老师。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: My mother’s infatuated with dieting.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我母亲沉溺于节食。

Sense.DEF: a strong feeling of love for someone or interest in something, especially a feeling that is unreasonable and does not continue for a long time

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the current infatuation with seventies style
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 当前对70年代风格的迷恋
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Shaw’s infatuation with the actress is evident in his writing.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 萧对那位女演员的迷恋在他的著作里表现得十分明显。

Sense.DEF: to give someone a disease
Sense.EXAMPLE: People with the virus may feel perfectly well, but they can still infect others.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 带有这种病毒的人可能毫无症状﹐却仍可能传染他人。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the number of people infected with HIV
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 艾滋病病毒感染者的数目

Sense.DEF: to make something contain something harmful that gives people a disease

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Eggs known to be infected with salmonella were allowed to go on sale.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 已知带有沙门氏菌的鸡蛋被允许销售。

Sense.DEF: if a feeling or interest that you have infects other people, it makes them begin to feel the same way or have the same interest
Sense.TRAN: 〔某种感情或兴趣〕感染﹐影响〔他人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lucy’s enthusiasm soon infected the rest of the class.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 露西的热情很快就感染了班里的其他人。

Sense.DEF: if a virus infects your computer or disk, it changes or destroys the information in or on it
a part of your body or a wound that is infected has harmful bacteria in it which prevent it from healing
Sense.EXAMPLE: an infected finger
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 受感染的手指
Sense.EXAMPLE: Clean the wound so it doesn’t get infected.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 清洗伤口以免感染。

Sense.DEF: food, water etc that is infected contains bacteria that spread disease
if a computer or disk is infected, the information in or on it has been changed or destroyed by a computer virus
Sense.TRAN: 〔计算机或磁盘〕受病毒感染的

Sense.DEF: a disease that affects a particular part of your body and is caused by bacteria or a virus
Sense.EXAMPLE: The baby had an ear infection.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宝宝耳朵感染了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an infection of the bladder
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 膀胱感染

Sense.DEF: when someone is infected by a disease
Sense.EXAMPLE: Always sterilize the needle to prevent infection.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 注射针头每次都要消毒﹐以防感染。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: I think you’ve got an infection, so you need to rest.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我认为你已被感染﹐因此需要休息。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He was suffering from an infection of the lungs.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他患上了肺部感染。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She got a nasty throat infection which meant she couldn’t sing.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她喉部严重感染﹐这意味着她不能唱歌了。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Antibiotics are used to treat the infection.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 抗生素被用来治疗这种感染。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: A new drug is being developed to combat the infection.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 正在研制一种新药来抵御传染。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Pregnant women can transmit the infection to their unborn child.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 孕妇会把这种疾病传染给胎儿。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The infection spread to her chest.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 感染扩散到她的胸部。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: goes away

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 暴露于易受感染的环境

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He was admitted to hospital with a serious infection.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因严重感染进了医院。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: not serious
Collocate.EXAMPLE: She’s suffering from a slight infection.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她受了轻度感染。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a serious infection
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He’s got a really nasty infection.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他受了很严重的感染。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a serious infection that develops suddenly
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The disease usually occurs as an acute infection of the throat.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种病的症状是喉部急性感染。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She was given antibiotics for an ear infection.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 医生给她开了抗生素治疗耳部感染。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: an infection in the lungs
caused by bacteria, a virus, or a fungus
Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 细菌/病毒/真菌引起的感染

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: an additional infection that happens as a result of the main illness

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Doctors are trying to locate the source of the infection.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 医生在设法找出传染源。

Sense.DEF: an infectious illness can be passed from one person to another, especially through the air you breathe
Sense.TRAN: 〔疾病〕传染性的〔尤指通过空气〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: infectious diseases
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 传染性疾病
Sense.EXAMPLE: Flu is highly infectious.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 流感传染性很强。

Sense.DEF: someone who is infectious has an illness and could pass it to other people
infectious feelings or laughter spread quickly from one person to another
Sense.EXAMPLE: an infectious smile
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有感染力的微笑
富有感染力的热情

Sense.DEF: to form an opinion that something is probably true because of information that you have

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A lot can be inferred from these statistics.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 根据这些统计资料可以推断出很多事情。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: From the evidence, we can infer that the victim knew her killer.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 根据证据我们可以推断出受害者认识凶手。

Sense.DEF: something that you think is true, based on information that you have

GramExa.EXAMPLE: What inferences have you drawn from this evidence?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你从这个证据中推论出了什么结果？

Sense.DEF: when someone infers something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was portrayed as a hero and, by inference, Thompson as the villain.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被描写成英雄﹐由此推论﹐汤普森则成了恶棍。

Sense.DEF: not good, or not as good as someone or something else
Sense.TRAN: 〔与其他人或物相比〕差的﹐次的
Sense.EXAMPLE: I felt very inferior among all those academics.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 与那些大学教师在一起﹐我自惭形秽。
Sense.EXAMPLE: wine of inferior quality
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 劣质葡萄酒
Sense.EXAMPLE: inferior goods
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 质量低劣的商品

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I always felt slightly inferior to her.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我总感觉比她稍逊一筹。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Their performance was inferior to that of other teams.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们的表现不如其他队。

Sense.DEF: lower in rank
Sense.EXAMPLE: an inferior court of law
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 初级法院﹔低级法院
Sense.EXAMPLE: He refused to accept a job of inferior status.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他拒绝接受职位低的工作。

Sense.DEF: someone who has a lower position or rank than you in an organization
when someone or something is not good or not as good as someone or something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: moral inferiority
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 道德低下

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He had a deep-rooted feeling of inferiority.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他有一种根深蒂固的自卑感。

Sense.DEF: a continuous feeling that you are much less important, clever etc than other people
used to express anger or annoyance about something
Sense.TRAN: 可恶的﹐恼人的〔用于表示愤怒或烦恼〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I wish the children would stop that infernal noise.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我真希望孩子们别再那么吵闹了。

Sense.DEF: relating to hell and evil
an extremely large and dangerous fire – used especially in news reports
Sense.TRAN: 熊熊大火﹐火海〔尤用于新闻报道〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Within minutes, the house had become a raging inferno.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 没几分钟房子就成了一片火海。

Sense.DEF: when someone has very strong feelings that are difficult to control
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was desperately trying to calm the inferno raging within her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她拼命想平息胸中的怒火。

Sense.DEF: unable to have babies
Sense.EXAMPLE: infertile couples
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不孕的夫妇

Sense.DEF: infertile land or soil is not good enough to grow plants in
when someone is unable to have a baby
Sense.EXAMPLE: There are many possible causes of infertility in women.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 妇女不孕可能有很多的原因。
Sense.EXAMPLE: infertility treatments
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不孕症的治疗

Sense.DEF: if insects, rats etc infest a place, there are a lot of them and they usually cause damage
Sense.TRAN: 〔昆虫﹑老鼠等〕成群侵扰﹐大批出没于

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The kitchen was infested with cockroaches.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 厨房里到处是蟑螂。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: shark-infested waters
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 鲨鱼成群出没的水域

Sense.DEF: if things or people you do not want infest a place, there are too many of them
Sense.EXAMPLE: an area infested with holiday homes
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 到处都是度假屋的地区

Sense.DEF: an offensive word for someone who has a different religion from you
when someone has sex with a person who is not their wife, husband, or partner
Sense.TRAN: 〔对丈夫﹑妻子或伴侣的〕不贞行为
Sense.EXAMPLE: marital infidelity
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对婚姻的不忠诚

Sense.DEF: the part of a cricket field nearest to the player who hits the ball
the part of a baseball field inside the four bases
the group of players in this part of the cricket or baseball field
Sense.TRAN: 〔板球的〕全体内场球员﹔〔棒球的〕全体内场手

Sense.DEF: when members of the same group or organization argue, or compete with each other in an unfriendly way
Sense.EXAMPLE: political infighting
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政治内讧

Sense.DEF: something that is used to fill a space
Sense.EXAMPLE: infill panels
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 内(镶)嵌板

Sense.DEF: the process of filling a space, especially by building new houses
Sense.EXAMPLE: infill developments
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 市区空地上新房的添建

Sense.DEF: to secretly join an organization or enter a place in order to find out information about it or harm it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Police attempts to infiltrate neo-Nazi groups were largely unsuccessful.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方想打入新纳粹团体的行动基本上不成功。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Rebel forces have been infiltrating into the country.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 叛军一直在向这个国家渗透。

Sense.DEF: to secretly put people into an organization or place in order to find out information or to harm it
Sense.TRAN: 使秘密进入﹐使潜入〔某组织或地方〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They repeatedly tried to infiltrate assassins into the palace.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们几次想让刺客潜入皇宫。

Sense.DEF: to become a part of something – used especially to show disapproval
Sense.EXAMPLE: Commercialism has been infiltrating universities for the past decade.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在过去十年里﹐商业主义已渗透进了大学。

Sense.DEF: very great in amount or degree
Sense.EXAMPLE: a woman of infinite patience
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 极有耐心的女子

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There was an infinite variety of drinks to choose from.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有各种各样的饮料可以选择。

Sense.DEF: without limits in space or time
Sense.TRAN: 〔空间或时间〕无限的﹐无穷无尽的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The universe is infinite.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宇宙是无限的。

Sense.DEF: very much – used especially when comparing things
Sense.EXAMPLE: This school is infinitely better than the last one I went to.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这所学校比我之前上的那一所好太多了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: someone with infinitely more experience
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经历丰富得多的人

Sense.DEF: extremely small
Sense.EXAMPLE: infinitesimal changes in temperature
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 气温极其微小的变化

Sense.DEF: in grammar, the basic form of a verb, used with ‘to’ in English. In the sentence ‘I want to watch television.’ ‘to watch’ is an infinitive.
Sense.TRAN: 〔动词的〕不定式〔英语语法中动词的基本形式﹐与to连用﹔I want to watch television一句中﹐to watch是不定式〕

Sense.DEF: a number or amount without limit
Sense.EXAMPLE: the vast infinitude of space
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宇宙的无限

Sense.DEF: a space or distance without limits or an end
Sense.EXAMPLE: the infinity of space
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 太空的无边无际

Sense.DEF: a number that is too large to be calculated
Sense.EXAMPLE: In the equation below, as E goes to zero, n approaches infinity.
